Although attendance at most
events over the Fall Break
weekend was "basically hurting," Jon Savitz, co-chairman
of the Fall Break Committee,
said he was pleased with the activities themselves.
"The attendance was basically hurting," Savitz said."A lot
of kids didn't show for a lot of
events."
While noting that many
students went home for the
three-day weekend, Savitz said
he was not sure exactly what accounted for the low attendance.
But despite the small crowds,
most of the events went
smoothly, Savitz said. The only event which didn't go well
was Thursday night's root beer
chugging contest at the Rat—
the root beer was never
delivered.
Various social events had
been scheduled throughout the
weekend, including a teepeebuilding contest, a marshmallow roast and hayride, a
scavenger hunt, a casino night,
a square dance and several concerts. The entire weekend was
organized around a Wild West
theme.
Savitz said that while he approves of the idea of holding a
"social weekend" in the fall
semester, he is not sure it
should be held on the same
weekend as Fall Break.
"That's got to be kicked
around," Savitz said.
Savitz also said that this
year's Fall Break Committee
suffered from two shortages:
money and time.

by Jeff Horn
The Seventeenth annual
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium, "Arms Control:
Strategy and Diplomacy" concluded Wednesday at Shriver
Hall with Ambassador Paul
Nitze, Secretary of State on
Arms Control Matters and
Special Advisor to the President,
and Mr. Dimitri Simes, Senior
Associate of the Carnegie Endowment for Peace and an expert on U.S./Soviet relations
speaking.
The final night of lectures entitled "Arms Control: A Look
Back," was introduced by
Charles Rowe, host of "Nightwatch" on CBS News.
Nitze began by giving a quick
diplomatic history of American/Soviet arms control
agreements and spoke about

bilateral negotiations in general
and the future of Reagan's
Strategic Defense Initiative
(SDI) in the context of arms
control.
A major aspect of any arms
control agreement, according to
both Nitze and Simes, is the
nature of the Soviet position.
To the Soviets, "arms control
is part of the continuing struggle against the non-Communist
world." The Soviets, said both
speakers, view political cohesion as important. They see the
differences in opinion among
the North Atlantic Treaty
Organization (NATO) countries as a weakness that is
susceptible to Soviet pressure
and manipulation.
The Soviets have a different
psychology concerning politics
than Americans do, concluded
both Nitze and Simes. The

Sex Revolution Over
According to Study
(CPS)—The sexual revolution seems to have ended on
campuses, some experts say.
Iowa State psychology professor Meg Gerrard's most recent survey of college sex habits
found far fewer "sexuallyactive" women on campus than
there were just a few years ago.
"My research clearly indicates that there is less sex on
campus than five years ago,"
she reports.
While other observers are
reluctant to endorse Gerrard's
conclusion, they do sense a
change in students' sexual
practices.
"I don't know if it is
statistically reliable to say there
has been a drop" in sex, says
Clive Davis, a Syracuse University pychology professor who

monitors sex research.
"At most, I would say there
might be a leveling off," Davis
concludes.
Gerrard bases her conclusion
on ongoing surveys of college
women since 1973.
In her first survey, Gerrard
found that about 34 percent of
the University of Texas-Austin
female students she asked were
"sexually active," having sex at
least once a month.
In 1978-79, Gerrard expanded her research to include
University of Kansas women,
too, and found that 51 percent
of the women at both schools
were sexually active.
"The late seventies were
definitely the height of the sexual revolution," she observes.

Howard E. Cooper, professor emeritus of The .,ohns
Hopkins University, died on
October 9 at his home in
Baltimore after a long battle
with diabetes. He will be
cremated. A memorial service
will be held on November 14 at
the Church of the Holy Comforter, BeIlona and Seminary
Roads, at 7 p.m. In addition, a
memorial service will be held on
November 15 in the lounge of
the Johns Hopkins Club, on the
University's Homewood campus, at 3 p.m.
Cooper is survived by his
daughter, Mary Cooper Evans,
of Oberlin, Ohio; grandchildren, Pamela Jo Evans,
David Cooper Evans and Mary
Elizabeth Evans Owens; and his
sister, Sister Edna, O.S.B. in
Chicago. Cooper's wife, the
former Mabel M. Eigler, died
in 1966. The family suggests, in
lieu of flowers, memorials to
the Howard E. Cooper
Memorial Scholarship Fund at
the Johns Hopkins University
School of Continuing Studies.
Cooper was born December
25, 1898, in Canon City, Colorado. Following service in Army intelligence during the First
World War, he attended the
University of Denver, where he
received a B.C.S. in 1923 and
a B.S. in 1925. He then studied
at Columbia University (M.S.,
1927) and The Johns Hopkins
University where he obtained a

Ph.D in accounting in 1932.
After teaching and administrative positions in
Denver, Cooper joined the
Hopkins faculty in 1928 as an
instructor of banking. He was
an associate professor in
Political Economy from
1943-46 and professor of accounting from 1946 until his
retirement in 1969 after nearly
42 years of service to Hopkins.
He was also associate dean of
the then McCoy College (now
School of Continying Studies)
from 1951 until his retirement.
Cooper was widely recognized
as an outstanding teacher—
scores of prominent Baltimorearea businessmen are numbered
among his former students. A
Baltimore Sun article noted
upon Cooper's retirement that
"This tall, friendly professor is
famous both for his interest
and success in common stock
investments. 'I've sort of
thrown my interests in investments and finance at my
students,' he said. 'The more
you know about individual
companies, the more you can
interest your students. A person
has to stimulate his students.'"
During the 1930s, Cooper
devoted his energies largely to
his investments. Having been
treasurer for nine years of the
Johns Hopkins Club, he remained active in the Club after
his retirement, frequently
eating lunch and dinner there.

The Future of Fall Break Of Tree Watching
Jon Savitz and Mark Goodman must
feel rejected: they gave a Fall Break and
nobody came.
The fault surely wasn't theirs,
however. Savitz and Goodman, cochairmen of the Fall Break Committee,
planned a welter (at least for Hopkins)
of social events for the weekend, almost
all of which went off quite well,
The problem is that attendance was
pitiful at most of the events.(Interestingly, though not surprisingly, Saturday's
Casino Night, with its alluring prospect
of cold hard cash, was the only event to
draw well.) Given a three-day weekend,
Hopkins students did what college
students anywhere would have done—
go home, get some good food and clean
clothes and escape the drudgeries of campus. In particular, the freshmen—on
whose attendance the success of campus
events depends—fled. (Some students
may also have done what college students
nowhere else would have done—study all
weekend.)
Savitz says thoughtfully that if a
"social weekend" of some sort is held
during the fall in future years, it ought
to be moved off of the Fall Break
weekend. He's right,
A weekend in the fall when people can
relax a little is certainly a good idea. One

of the things that traditionally made the
fall semester seem so interminable was
not only the lack of a break, but the lack
of almost any excitement. Weekends in
the spring, on the other hand, are
brightened up by both Spring Fair and
lacrosse games.
But to work hard organizing events
scheduled for a weekend when no one is
on campus just doesn't make any sense.
So when discussions about the future of
Fall Break come up, two decisions need
to be made. First, don't plan anything
special for the weekend of the break. In
fact, don't plan anything at all.
Recognize the fact that students will
either go home or bury themselves on Dlevel, and accept that the campus will be
dead that weekend. Second, plan some
sort of a social weekend well before or
after Fall Break. (And well before or
after mid-terms, which had to c3ntribute
to this year's paltry attendance.)
The problem with this year's break
was certainly no one's fault. Savitz and
Goodman worked hard to organize the
events; students can hardly be blamed
for taking the opportunity to go home.
The important thing now is to change the
plans for next year—and avoid making
the same mistakes twice.

Some Symposium Reforms
Since this year's Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium has just drawn to a close,
allow us a few reflections on the future
of the event.
Before this year's series started, we
mentioned we thought the list of
speakers was improved over the last few
years. That's very true, but we also have
more radical changes to suggest. To truly
reach its potential, the symposium will
have to undergo some major alterations.
Later this year, when Student Council
Vice-President Mary Hiatt and the Cornmittee on Committees (of which she is
chairman) picks next year's symposium
chairmen, they should find people willing to implement the necessary reforms.
For one thing, future chairmen should
no longer concern themselves too greatly with limiting the series to a few weeks,
or to developing some chronological
symmetry for it (holding all the lectures
on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, for exampie). In the past, that has often caused
problems. Potential speakers are given
a few dates on which the symposium will
be held, and if they are busy, they are
automatically eliminated from speaking.
How much easier it would be to recruit
speakers if the symposium were held
throughout the fall semester, allowing
the chairman to fit the symposium to the
(very crowded) schedules of desired
speakers.
Some will no doubt say that people
would forget about the series and attendance would fall if it was spread over
several months, but if better speakers
were enlisted surely the opposite would
happen.
An even more important reform,

however, is a broadening of the symposium's topic. The last three years the
series has focused on arms control, terrorism and "the dynamics of foreign
policy"—all much too political. Instead,
let's look for something that would interest a wider variety of students. A few
suggestions:
'American Medicine in the 21st
Century—Speakers could examine
technological questions, medical ethics
and political problems facing the medical
world.(Ought there to be national health
insurance?, for example.)
*American Culture: Does it Exist?—
Is there a uniquely American culture? Is
there a uniquely American body of
music? Of film? Of literature? A list of
possible speakers for this one is almost
endless, and they could take any angle
they wanted.
'Today's Youth: Are They As Bad As
Everyone Says?—We keep hearing that
college students today are so apathetic,
concerned more about making money
than making a difference in the world.
Is that so? And if so, is that bad?
The point is that symposium topics
recently have suffered from nothing so
much as being too narrow. The topic
ought to be some sort of general idea—
an idea on which speakers can expand
in any direction they want.
This year's symposium did have better speakers than the last few. But unless
some major changes are made in the
structure of the series, the decline of the
last few years will probably continue.
When it comes time to pick next year's
chairmen, the COC should have the
courage to make those changes.

by Elizabeth Harrigan
The embarrassed pre-frosh
squirmed in his seat as his
father asked the group of Blue
Key Society members,"What is
the alcohol policy here at
Hopkins?"
Rich Dynes looked the man
straight in the eye and
answered, "Mandatory, sir.
Mandatory."
Perhaps Dynes was a little
more lighthearted that day than
usual. However, the Blue Key
members have a tough job in
that they must appeal to both
parents and students in their
portrayal of Johns Hopkins.
But they also have the opportunity to help shape the face of
a class.
According to Dynes, "I try
to attract high-energy students,
and I have to show that energy
in myself to get them to come
to school here."
The Blue Key Society, a
volunteer student-run organization, does more than just give
tours to visiting pre-freshmen.
They help out in the Admissions Office and serve as
representatives to high schools.
However, the tours give the
members a chance to show off
their Hopkins trivia, as well as
show off Hopkins. Believe it or
not, this tour has been the
deciding factor for quite a few
students—for example, Dynes
knows of eight freshmen who
are here this year because of last
April's Open House tour.

Chrysso Sarkos, Blue Key
Vice President, said, "I've had
people tell me that they did not
want to attend Hopkins before
they took my tour. And now
they're here."
This does not surprise anyone who knows Sarkos, because
she is truly outstanding. She is
famous within the society for
being the only tour guide ever
to be taken out to dinner by the
family of a pre-frosh. Her tour
is packed with details about
Hopkins, and she knows how
to appeal to different types of
people. "If someone is a history
buff, I might take them over to
Shriver and tell them all about
the murals in the lobby," said
Sarkos. If they are very serious
and concerned mostly with the
academics, she'll emphasize
that on her tour.
Each tour is very different.
Sarkos loves to show off the
dorm furniture, especially the

Telling It
Like It Is

chairs that tip back but never
fall over. She was once demonstrating this for a family when
she got too carried away and
fell flat on her face! Dynes
recently had some of the
members of his tour pose as upperclassmen for the yearbook
photos.(So when you are going
through your yearbook next
spring and the names Don
Bucklin and Mark Read don't
ring a bell, don't be surprised.
They're not really Hopkins
juniors—they're high school
seniors from Bethesda. And
yes, they did each receive a
dollar for posing.)
The tours can also depend
upon the family members present. "Mothers dominate all the
time," laughs Sarkos. "One
mom actually asked me,'What
is the percentage of geeks at this
school?'"She also is often asked by moms, "Have you seen
a lot of DRU 9"

The Blue Key members frequently get difficult questions
like, "Well, what do you hate
about Hopkins?", or even,
"What were your SAT
scores?" To Sarkos, the SAT is
certainly not of the greatest importance for getting in, and she
hates to see pre-frosh so concerned with them.
Both Sarkos and Dynes stress
that it is important to be extremely positive about Hopkins, but that they are always
totally honest. Sarkos, for example, has often been asked
about the security. She tells
them that there are risks, but
emphasizes services such as the
security van and quad
monitors.
The Blue Key members work
hard at involving the pre-frosh
in conversation during the
tours. "I make them guess what
the modern sculpture in the
lower quad is," said Sarkos.
She said she loves Hopkins, and
loves trying to get people to
come here. "A tour is a great
break from the usual complaints about Hopkins. For
once you can say a lot of good
things about the place to people who really want to hear
them," she said.
Dynes really enjoys the very
responsive, fun-loving prefrosh because he can relate to
them very well. "People want
to go to a school that is like
themselves," said Dynes. Obviously, Blue Key is one place
where Hopkins apathy simply
does not exist.

The Burn, by Vassily Aksyonov, is a book presenting a

Originally published in 1980, the
English translation, published

until 1984. Although it is
somewhat entertaining and is
Probably faithful in portraying
the sort of existence led by this
social class, it is very difficult
to follow, and, as suggested by
a Russian friend of mine, is
Probably not very meaningful
to someone who has not had
first-hand experience with that
segment of Russian society.
The book is written in a mixture of three styles of writing.
Parts are from an objective
Point of view; these are the
easiest parts of the book to
read, for they contain few surprises: when something
changes, the reader is informed. A few passages are written
in a style which approaches
stream-of-conJoyce's
sciousness in confusing the
reader. These parts are very
hard to understand, and might
almost be omitted on first
reading.
The majority of the book,
however, is written in first person point of view from the
Main character. This is not so
bad; generally no major shifts,
such as the extensive flashbacks
employed by Aksyonov, occur
Within any such passages. The
Most confusing aspect of this
Point of view is that the identity of the main character
Changes throughout the course
of the book. Although it is
Clearly one individual, he ap-

pears under five names, each
with a different profession, and
united only by the patronymic
(middle name taken from the
given name of the father) of
Apollinarievich. The parallel
lives led by these characters is
brought home very clearly early in the novel as a scene is
replayed by Aksyonov five
times, as Apollinarievich comes
first out of a jazz cafe, then a
scientific meeting, then an
operating room, then his
studio, and finally a reception
at the Brazilian Embassy, to
meet his mistress Masha and his
American friend Patrick
Thunderjet in a black Impala.
A single coherent plot is not
apparent throughout the book.
The principal aim seems to be

generation of Russian thinkers,

skillfully.

with diabetes. He will be
cremated. A memorial service

memorial service will be held on
November 15 in the lounge of
the Johns Hopkins Club, on the
University's Homewood campus, at 3 p.m.

daughter, Mary Cooper Evans,

Elizabeth Evans Owens; and his
sister, Sister Edna, O.S.B. in

lieu of flowers, memorials to
the Howard E. Cooper
Memorial Scholarship Fund at

University where he obtained a

Denver, Cooper joined the
Hopkins faculty in 1928 as an
instructor of banking. He was
an associate professor in

companies, the more you can
interest your students. A person

devoted his energies largely to
his investments. Having been
treasurer for nine years of the
Johns Hopkins Club, he remained active in the Club after
his retirement, frequently
eating lunch and dinner there.

Jon Savitz and Mark Goodman must
feel rejected: they gave a Fall Break and
nobody came.
The fault surely wasn't theirs,
however. Savitz and Goodman, cochairmen of the Fall Break Committee,
planned a welter (at least for Hopkins)
of social events for the weekend, almost
all of which went off quite well,
The problem is that attendance was
pitiful at most of the events.(Interestingly, though not surprisingly, Saturday's
Casino Night, with its alluring prospect
of cold hard cash, was the only event to
draw well.) Given a three-day weekend,
Hopkins students did what college
students anywhere would have done—
go home, get some good food and clean
clothes and escape the drudgeries of campus. In particular, the freshmen—on
whose attendance the success of campus
events depends—fled. (Some students
may also have done what college students
nowhere else would have done—study all
weekend.)
Savitz says thoughtfully that if a
"social weekend" of some sort is held
during the fall in future years, it ought
to be moved off of the Fall Break
weekend. He's right,
A weekend in the fall when people can
relax a little is certainly a good idea. One

of the things that traditionally made the
fall semester seem so interminable was
not only the lack of a break, but the lack
of almost any excitement. Weekends in
the spring, on the other hand, are
brightened up by both Spring Fair and
lacrosse games.
But to work hard organizing events
scheduled for a weekend when no one is
on campus just doesn't make any sense.
So when discussions about the future of
Fall Break come up, two decisions need
to be made. First, don't plan anything
special for the weekend of the break. In
fact, don't plan anything at all.
Recognize the fact that students will
either go home or bury themselves on Dlevel, and accept that the campus will be
dead that weekend. Second, plan some
sort of a social weekend well before or
after Fall Break. (And well before or
after mid-terms, which had to c3ntribute
to this year's paltry attendance.)
The problem with this year's break
was certainly no one's fault. Savitz and
Goodman worked hard to organize the
events; students can hardly be blamed
for taking the opportunity to go home.
The important thing now is to change the
plans for next year—and avoid making
the same mistakes twice.

Some Symposium Reforms
Since this year's Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium has just drawn to a close,
allow us a few reflections on the future
of the event.
Before this year's series started, we
mentioned we thought the list of
speakers was improved over the last few
years. That's very true, but we also have
more radical changes to suggest. To truly
reach its potential, the symposium will
have to undergo some major alterations.
Later this year, when Student Council
Vice-President Mary Hiatt and the Cornmittee on Committees (of which she is
chairman) picks next year's symposium
chairmen, they should find people willing to implement the necessary reforms.
For one thing, future chairmen should
no longer concern themselves too greatly with limiting the series to a few weeks,
or to developing some chronological
symmetry for it (holding all the lectures
on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, for exampie). In the past, that has often caused
problems. Potential speakers are given
a few dates on which the symposium will
be held, and if they are busy, they are
automatically eliminated from speaking.
How much easier it would be to recruit
speakers if the symposium were held
throughout the fall semester, allowing
the chairman to fit the symposium to the
(very crowded) schedules of desired
speakers.
Some will no doubt say that people
would forget about the series and attendance would fall if it was spread over
several months, but if better speakers
were enlisted surely the opposite would
happen.
An even more important reform,

however, is a broadening of the symposium's topic. The last three years the
series has focused on arms control, terrorism and "the dynamics of foreign
policy"—all much too political. Instead,
let's look for something that would interest a wider variety of students. A few
suggestions:
'American Medicine in the 21st
Century—Speakers could examine
technological questions, medical ethics
and political problems facing the medical
world.(Ought there to be national health
insurance?, for example.)
*American Culture: Does it Exist?—
Is there a uniquely American culture? Is
there a uniquely American body of
music? Of film? Of literature? A list of
possible speakers for this one is almost
endless, and they could take any angle
they wanted.
'Today's Youth: Are They As Bad As
Everyone Says?—We keep hearing that
college students today are so apathetic,
concerned more about making money
than making a difference in the world.
Is that so? And if so, is that bad?
The point is that symposium topics
recently have suffered from nothing so
much as being too narrow. The topic
ought to be some sort of general idea—
an idea on which speakers can expand
in any direction they want.
This year's symposium did have better speakers than the last few. But unless
some major changes are made in the
structure of the series, the decline of the
last few years will probably continue.
When it comes time to pick next year's
chairmen, the COC should have the
courage to make those changes.

The embarrassed pre-frosh
squirmed in his seat as his
father asked the group of Blue
Key Society members,"What is
the alcohol policy here at
Hopkins?"
Rich Dynes looked the man
straight in the eye and
answered, "Mandatory, sir.
Mandatory."
Perhaps Dynes was a little
more lighthearted that day than
usual. However, the Blue Key
members have a tough job in
that they must appeal to both
parents and students in their
portrayal of Johns Hopkins.
But they also have the opportunity to help shape the face of
a class.
According to Dynes, "I try
to attract high-energy students,
and I have to show that energy
in myself to get them to come
to school here."
The Blue Key Society, a
volunteer student-run organization, does more than just give
tours to visiting pre-freshmen.
They help out in the Admissions Office and serve as
representatives to high schools.
However, the tours give the
members a chance to show off
their Hopkins trivia, as well as
show off Hopkins. Believe it or
not, this tour has been the
deciding factor for quite a few
students—for example, Dynes
knows of eight freshmen who
are here this year because of last
April's Open House tour.

Chrysso Sarkos, Blue Key
Vice President, said, "I've had
people tell me that they did not
want to attend Hopkins before
they took my tour. And now
they're here."
This does not surprise anyone who knows Sarkos, because
she is truly outstanding. She is
famous within the society for
being the only tour guide ever
to be taken out to dinner by the
family of a pre-frosh. Her tour
is packed with details about
Hopkins, and she knows how
to appeal to different types of
people. "If someone is a history
buff, I might take them over to
Shriver and tell them all about
the murals in the lobby," said
Sarkos. If they are very serious
and concerned mostly with the
academics, she'll emphasize
that on her tour.
Each tour is very different.
Sarkos loves to show off the
dorm furniture, especially the

Telling It
Like It Is

chairs that tip back but never
fall over. She was once demonstrating this for a family when
she got too carried away and
fell flat on her face! Dynes
recently had some of the
members of his tour pose as upperclassmen for the yearbook
photos.(So when you are going
through your yearbook next
spring and the names Don
Bucklin and Mark Read don't
ring a bell, don't be surprised.
They're not really Hopkins
juniors—they're high school
seniors from Bethesda. And
yes, they did each receive a
dollar for posing.)
The tours can also depend
upon the family members present. "Mothers dominate all the
time," laughs Sarkos. "One
mom actually asked me,'What
is the percentage of geeks at this
school?'"She also is often asked by moms, "Have you seen
a lot of DRU 9"

The Blue Key members frequently get difficult questions
like, "Well, what do you hate
about Hopkins?", or even,
"What were your SAT
scores?" To Sarkos, the SAT is
certainly not of the greatest importance for getting in, and she
hates to see pre-frosh so concerned with them.
Both Sarkos and Dynes stress
that it is important to be extremely positive about Hopkins, but that they are always
totally honest. Sarkos, for example, has often been asked
about the security. She tells
them that there are risks, but
emphasizes services such as the
security van and quad
monitors.
The Blue Key members work
hard at involving the pre-frosh
in conversation during the
tours. "I make them guess what
the modern sculpture in the
lower quad is," said Sarkos.
She said she loves Hopkins, and
loves trying to get people to
come here. "A tour is a great
break from the usual complaints about Hopkins. For
once you can say a lot of good
things about the place to people who really want to hear
them," she said.
Dynes really enjoys the very
responsive, fun-loving prefrosh because he can relate to
them very well. "People want
to go to a school that is like
themselves," said Dynes. Obviously, Blue Key is one place
where Hopkins apathy simply
does not exist.

Probably not very meaningful
